intro: Draba claviformis, commonly known as the club-shaped whitlowgrass, is a small flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and western Asia. It belongs to the Brassicaceae family, which includes mustard and cabbages, and is characterized by its tiny, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine habitats, thriving in well-drained soils at high altitudes. It produces small, capsule-like fruits that contain several seeds, which are dispersed by wind. Draba claviformis is often found in open, sunny areas and is adapted to cold climates.
